There’s a non-zero amount of people I generally respect the opinions of who will assert that Mamma Mia isn’t a memory game, on the grounds that even if information was perfectly tracked, you still wouldn’t be able to account for the small amount of cards left in player hands and messing with the topping/order conveyor belt. That is missing the point, though: games may have more than one mechanic, and if the argument is that a game that’s only 90-95% memory doesn’t qualify for the label "memory game", I won’t dispute your right to define words however your want, but that doesn’t make the definition very useful.

Absolutely nobody would want to play a perfectly tracked version of Mamma Mia, because it would be utterly boring. Similarly, nobody would have a realistic chance at winning (against people playing normally) if they outright mentally skipped their opponents’ turns, because there is about no board state to observe. Ergo, this is by my account a sodding memory game - call it "fuzzy" or whatever diplomatic middle ground you will - with all my utter disinterest for the genre.

What I like:
- Clever memory and push-your-luck game with a fun pizza-making theme. Players play ingredient cards to a communal pile and can declare they're making one of their pizzas. The trick is remembering what's already in the pile from previous turns to know if you have enough ingredients to complete your order.
- Creates great tension when deciding whether to declare a pizza. Do I have all the ingredients I need, or am I missing something? Did other players contribute the cards I'm lacking?
- The evaluation phases are satisfying moments where everyone finds out which pizzas succeed and which fail. Successfully completing a pizza after tracking ingredients through multiple rounds feels rewarding.
- Plays quickly and works well as a lighter game that still requires attention and strategy.

What I dislike:
- Heavy reliance on memory can be frustrating if you lose track of what's been played. Especially bad if players are pretty tired (as it was the case with me).
- The randomness of card draws can sometimes leave you stuck with recipes you can't realistically complete based on the ingredients you're holding.
A fun little filler, especially good for kids. While I think I still own this, I can't find it, so I may want to find another copy somewhere.

Amusing, swingy quest fulfillment game that also doubles as a pseudo-memory game. It's only somewhat memory-based, because you can't know what's in others' hands, and this informs the fulfillment along with the game's public knowledge. Which is great, because decisions are still informed, but it becomes more gut-based than strictly calculative.

It's ultimately a bit too random for some, too memory-dependent for others, and you can know you're just playing for pride with a third (or more) of the game left to go. So it hasn't been universally successful with those I've played with. But it consistently amuses me, and that's enough.

A firecracker of a game!

Pros:
The rules are dead-simple and produce a lot of laughs. It's a game that anyone can play and it's fast, it should be a staple game in many collections.

I love how it uses memory, in the beginning of a round it's quite easy to keep track of things and by the end people are pretty much just guessing, hoping someone else got something wrong earlier. I also like that you can compensate for mistakes by using ingredients from hand, sometimes even on purpose.

I like the hand management, it's good to dump a bunch of ingredients as you get the first chance to play a pizza on them and get to redraw a lot, but to get that opportunity you need to get lucky, have few pizzas in hand, and/or spend time slowly dumping singles. You also sometimes want to save some ingredients for the end of the round, and you have to consider when to draw pizzas to increase you options at the cost of your hand limit.

I love how ingredients stay on the table until they're used. It makes subsequent rounds different and benefits players that push the end of a round, while also adding an element of chaos to the memory aspect.

Cons:
I think the symbology for the special pizzas could have been a lot better. Why J and ? instead of something like = and < ? Also, a reminder that the big pizza uses all ingredients wouldn't hurt.

There's a slight runaway leader problem in that if someone has very few pizzas left to make they can keep all their options available without sacrificing too much of their hand size, and they can more easily focus on playing ingredients that fit the pizzas they have left. This is very minor though, and the game probably shouldn't be played at a level where this is relevant.

Playing this with someone with perfect memory would break the game, but the same is true for any memory game.

A strange unique game combining memory and bluffing. Kind of like Nana in a way, but I can't think of much else. What makes this one special is how it seems so simple and logical at the start, then a few players make errors/bluffs, and nobody can keep track of what's available. Everythng just collapses, and everyone scrambles for scraps. For that reason it feels like the total opposite of Nana's arc despite very similar building blocks (in Nana things get easier to narrow down, but the stakes go up, so players bluff to confuse those who are ahead. hence it's more focused on mindgames than memory). So while I love this too, it seems more tuned for children laughing as order falls apart... pretentious adults have trouble with that concept.
